alleviate.definition: provide physical relief, as from pain

apathy.definition: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm

arduous.definition: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion

shun.definition: avoid and stay away from deliberately

shunt.definition: a conductor diverting a fraction of current from a device

skeptical.definition: marked by or given to doubt

sketchy.definition: giving only major points; lacking completeness

skiff.definition: a small boat propelled by oars or by sails or by a motor

smother.definition: deprive of oxygen and prevent from breathing

sober.definition: not affected by a chemical substance, especially alcohol

spell.definition: write or name the letters that comprise the accepted form of

spendthrift.definition: someone who spends money freely or wastefully

spine.definition: the series of vertebrae forming the backbone

stake.definition: a strong wooden or metal post driven into the ground

steadfast.definition: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable

stiff.definition: incapable of or resistant to bending

stigmatize.definition: condemn or openly brand as disgraceful

stockade.definition: fortification consisting of a fence set firmly for defense

stoop.definition: bend one's back forward from the waist on down

stray.definition: wander from a direct course or at random

subdue.definition: put down by force or intimidation

suborn.definition: incite to commit a crime or an evil deed

substantial.definition: real; having a material or factual existence

supplicate.definition: ask for humbly or earnestly, as in prayer

susceptible.definition: yielding readily to or capable of

tangible.definition: perceptible by the senses, especially the sense of touch

tapestry.definition: a wall hanging of heavy fabric with pictorial designs

tarnish.definition: make or become dirty or spotty

tenable.definition: based on sound reasoning or evidence

tentative.definition: hesitant or lacking confidence; unsettled in mind or opinion

torment.definition: intense feelings of suffering; acute mental or physical pain

torpid.definition: in a condition of biological rest or suspended animation

traitor.definition: a person who says one thing and does another

trample.definition: tread or stomp heavily or roughly

transgress.definition: act in disregard of laws, rules, contracts, or promises

tremor.definition: an involuntary vibration, as if from illness or fear

trepidation.definition: a feeling of alarm or dread

truce.definition: a state of peace agreed to between opponents

unequivocal.definition: admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding

untenable.definition: incapable of being defended or justified

untoward.definition: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is proper

uphold.definition: stand up for; stick up for; of causes, principles, or ideals

uproar.definition: a state of commotion and noise and confusion

usurp.definition: seize and take control without authority

vagary.definition: an unexpected and inexplicable change in something

vagrant.definition: a wanderer with no established residence or means of support

valiant.definition: having or showing heroism or courage

varnish.definition: a coating that provides a hard, lustrous finish to a surface

vertigo.definition: a reeling sensation; a feeling that you are about to fall

vigilance.definition: the process of paying close and continuous attention

vindicate.definition: show to be right by providing justification or proof

vindictive.definition: disposed to seek revenge or intended for revenge

vogue.definition: a current state of general acceptance and use

volubility.definition: the quality of being facile in speech and writing

voluptuous.definition: displaying luxury and furnishing gratification to the senses

voracious.definition: devouring or craving food in great quantities

vulnerable.definition: capable of being wounded or hurt

wardrobe.definition: a piece of furniture that provides storage space for clothes

waver.definition: pause or hold back in uncertainty or unwillingness

wheedle.definition: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering

wile.definition: the use of tricks to deceive someone

withhold.definition: hold back; refuse to hand over or share
withhold.example:
By doing so, we are 
withholding from our neediest students any reason to read at all.New York Times (Apr 23, 2012)

zenith.definition: the point above the observer directly opposite the nadir
zenith.example:
Performance increased at a slower pace after age 20, reaching a 
zenith of 83 percent correct responses for study volunteers between ages 30 and 34.

zephyr.example:
Thy 
zephyrs soft, thy falling showers, No more have charms for me; Maternal Summer, too, adieu!—Ballou, Maturin Murray
